edu.brown.cs.systems.tracingplane.atom_layer

Interface AtomLayer<B extends BaggageAtoms>

  • Type Parameters:
    B - Some implementation of Baggage used by this transit layer.
    All Superinterfaces:
    TransitLayer<B>
    All Known Subinterfaces:
    BaggageLayer<B>
    All Known Implementing Classes:
    GenericBaggageLayer, RawAtomLayer

    public interface AtomLayer<B extends BaggageAtoms>
extends TransitLayer<B>

    The AtomLayer is an implementation of the TransitLayer that specifies some default behavior for how to branch, join, and serialize Baggage. The AtomLayer provides the minimal implementation necessary for an application to participate in the tracing plane. The AtomLayer enables an application to propagate Baggage without needing to know about what data it contains or the semantics of that data.

    The AtomLayer implementation of Baggage is BaggageAtoms, which is simply a list of atoms. At atom is an arbitrary-length array of bytes, and most of the APIs for dealing with atoms just use ByteBuffer objects for atoms. The AtomLayer is not responsible for understanding the contents of each individual atom. It simply sees baggage as a list of atoms. For example, it might receive baggage with the following atoms: 

     
 [F8, 00]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 07]
 [F8, 01]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0A]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 14]

    The AtomLayer does not attempt to interpret the meaning of these bytes. However, it does specify logic for how to merge the atoms for multiple baggage instances, how to drop atoms if a baggage instance is too large, and how to serialize atoms, as follows:

    • Atoms are serialized by prefixing the bytes of each atom with their length (encoded as a protobuf-style varint). For the example above, the serialized representation would be: 
       
 [ 02, F8, 00,                               // first atom length then payload
   09, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 07,   // second atom length then payload
   02, F8, 01,                               // third atom length then payload
   09, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0A,   // fourth atom length then payload
   09, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 14 ]  // fifth atom length then payload
      See the AtomLayerSerialization class for more information about serialization.
    • If we have two baggage instances that are joining, we join the baggages by merging their atoms lexicographically. During the lexicographic merge, if we encounter duplicate atoms we only include the atom once. For example, suppose we have a second list of atoms: 
       
 [F8, 00]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 07]
 [F8, 01]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0F]
      The lexicographic merge of these second atoms with the first lot of atoms above would be: 
       
 [F8, 00]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 07]
 [F8, 01]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0A]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0F]
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 14]
      See the Lexicographic class for more information about lexicographic merging.
    • If we need to reduce the size of baggage, we do so by dropping atoms from the end of the list of atoms. Some systems might have a hard upper limit on baggage size (e.g., no more than 100 bytes in size). Additionally, if atoms are dropped then an OVERFLOW_MARKER should be appended to the end of the list of atoms. The overflow marker is the empty atom (e.g., zero-length atom) which is lexicographically smaller than all other atoms and therefore tracks the position in the baggage where data was dropped. For example, if our system was extremely capacity-conscious (say, 30 byte limit on baggage size), we would overflow the baggage as follows: 
       
 [F8, 00]                                // serialized size 3   (total 3)
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 07]    // serialized size 10  (total 13)
 [F8, 01]                                // serialized size 3   (total 16)
 [00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 00, 0A]    // serialized size 10  (total 26)
 []                                      // cannot include next atom, so put overflow marker  (total 27)
      See the AtomLayerOverflow class for more information about overflow.

    For a system to participate in the tracing plane, it must be capable of propagating at least two bytes of baggage.

    The methods in this class are similar to the methods defined by TransitLayer, with atoms(BaggageAtoms) and wrap(List) replacing TransitLayer.serialize(Baggage) and TransitLayer.deserialize(byte[], int, int).
